meanings.definition: To place or position something before something else.
meanings.sent1: She enjoys preposing her favorite book on the top shelf.
meanings.sent2: I always prepose my keys by the door so I don't forget them.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous squirrel preposed the acorn in the bird's nest.
meanings.sent4: His kindness preposed a ray of hope in her heart.
meanings.sent5: Preposing the flowers in the vase made the room feel brighter.

meanings.definition: To move something to the front or beginning of a sentence or phrase.
meanings.sent1: Before submitting the report, she decided to prepose the conclusion.
meanings.sent2: In academic writing, it is common to prepose the thesis statement.
meanings.sent3: The comedian preposed a punchline at the start of his joke, surprising the audience.
meanings.sent4: Her laughter preposed a sense of joy in the room.
meanings.sent5: Preposing the question at the beginning of the interview set the tone for the discussion.
